title: Britain's Buy-To-Let boom gathers pace
text:
Lending to landlords has jumped 40 per cen year on year GETTY Mortgage lending is tipped to remain strong in the coming weeks 
In the coming months experts are predicting lending to remain strong, particularly as mortgage rates are tipped to stay low for some time yet. This week provider Accord launched a 1.84 per cent two-year fixed mortgage for landlords, while Chelsea Building Society has gone after first-time buyers with the launch of a 1.82 per cent two-year loan fix for buyers with a deposit of just 15 per cent. Mark Harris, chief executive of mortgage broker SPF Private Clients, said: "Fixed rates on buy-to-let mortgages have moved below two per cent for the first time - a phenomenally low rate which will be attractive to landlords keen to keep costs down since the changes to mortgage interest tax relief announced in the Summer Budget. "Buy-to-let lending saw considerable year-on-year increases and the attraction of the sector is undiminished, even if landlords may think twice in the future before investing to ensure the numbers add up."With first-time buyers accounting for 44 per cent of total lending volumes, a much higher proportion than pre-crisis levels of 30 per cent, the trend for lenders to offer higher loan-to-value mortgages continues."
